Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 208,.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws, Chapter 208, Section 28, which governs jurisdiction in cases of custody and support.

Tibbetts v. Tibbetts, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 1.raw_text: Tibbetts v. Tibbetts, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 157 (1980)
Tibbetts v. Tibbetts, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 1.proposition: WHEREFORE, the Plaintiff respectfully requests that this Honorable Court grant the requested modification of the custody order and any other relief that it deems just and proper.
Tibbetts v. Tibbetts, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 1.support_reasoning: The proposition is a generic request for modification of a custody order and for other just and proper relief, i.e., a standard prayer for relief in a family/custody context. Tibbetts v. Tibbetts is a Massachusetts criminal case involving rape and insanity, addressing evidentiary and prosecutorial issues, not custody, modification standards, or the scope of relief in domestic relations matters. The opinion does not discuss custody orders or such a concluding prayer, so it does not support the claimed proposition.

Carpenter v. Carpenter, 407 Mass. 618 (1.proposition: WHEREFORE, the Plaintiff respectfully requests that this Honorable Court grant the requested modification of the custody order and any other relief that it deems just and proper.
Carpenter v. Carpenter, 407 Mass. 618 (1.support_reasoning: The proposition is a standard boilerplate request in a family/custody pleading asking the court to grant a modification of custody and other just and proper relief. Carpenter v. Carpenter is a criminal procedure case about warrantless searches, exigent circumstances, and suppression of evidence; it does not concern custody, family law, or standards for modifying custody orders. Nothing in the opinion addresses or provides authority for the quoted request language or any related custody principle.

Bower v. Bournay-Bower, 469 Mass. 690 (2.proposition: WHEREFORE, the Plaintiff respectfully requests that this Honorable Court grant the requested modification of the custody order and any other relief that it deems just and proper.
Bower v. Bournay-Bower, 469 Mass. 690 (2.support_reasoning: The proposition is a generic request for modification of a custody order and for any further relief the court deems just and proper. Bower v. Bournay-Bower addresses the limits of a Probate and Family Court judge’s inherent authority to appoint a parenting coordinator and to delegate binding decision-making authority, not the standards or form of pleading for modification of custody or general prayers for relief. The opinion does not discuss or endorse the quoted ‘wherefore’ language or any similar procedural request, so it does not support the proposition for which it is cited.
Bower v. Bournay-Bower, 469 Mass. 690 (2.relevant_excerpt: “By statute, if a party seeks a modification of a final judgment of divorce, a judge may make a judgment modifying his or her earlier judgment provided the judge finds that ‘a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children.’ G. L. c. 208, § 28.”

E.N.O. v. L.M.M., 429 Mass. 824 (1999).proposition: WHEREFORE, the Plaintiff respectfully requests that this Honorable Court grant the requested modification of the custody order and any other relief that it deems just and proper.
E.N.O. v. L.M.M., 429 Mass. 824 (1999).support_reasoning: The proposition is merely a generic request in an ad damnum clause asking the court to grant a modification of custody and other proper relief. E.N.O. v. L.M.M. concerns a de facto parent’s right to seek visitation under the Probate Court’s equity jurisdiction and the best-interests standard; it does not speak to pleading formalities or endorse that particular boilerplate request language. Therefore, the case does not provide authority for the proposition as stated.
E.N.O. v. L.M.M., 429 Mass. 824 (1999).relevant_excerpt: "The defendant asks us also to address whether the plaintiff may seek adoption or custody of the child and whether a coparenting agreement executed by the parties is specifically enforceable. The only issue before the single justice was the propriety of the temporary visitation order. The plaintiff’s custody, adoption, and financial claims are still pending in the Probate Court. We do not reach these issues."

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: WHEREFORE, the Plaintiff respectfully requests that this Honorable Court grant the requested modification of the custody order and any other relief that it deems just and proper.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The proposition is simply the standard boilerplate ‘wherefore’ clause requesting that the court grant a modification of custody and any other just relief. Mason v. Coleman concerns the substantive standard for child removal and best interests analysis in joint custody relocation cases; it does not establish any rule about the form or propriety of such a wherefore clause or about a party’s entitlement to relief merely because it is requested. Thus the opinion does not provide authority for that procedural proposition.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: WHEREFORE, the Plaintiff respectfully requests that this Honorable Court grant the requested modification of the custody order and any other relief that it deems just and proper.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The proposition is simply a stock request in a prayer for relief asking the court to grant a modification of a custody order and any other just and proper relief. Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas concerns standards for initial custody determinations and removal of children from the jurisdiction, not the form or propriety of such boilerplate prayer language. The opinion does not discuss or establish any rule about requesting modifications or using ‘any other relief that it deems just and proper’ language, so it does not support the specific proposition cited.

Kulko v. Superior Court of California, 4.raw_text: Kulko v. Superior Court of California, 436 U.S. 84 (1978)
Kulko v. Superior Court of California, 4.proposition: WHEREFORE, the Plaintiff respectfully requests that this Honorable Court grant the requested modification of the custody order and any other relief that it deems just and proper.
Kulko v. Superior Court of California, 4.case_name: Kulko v. Superior Court of Cal., City and County of San Francisco
Kulko v. Superior Court of California, 4.support_reasoning: The proposition is a boilerplate request for relief in a custody modification motion, not a substantive legal standard. Kulko concerns personal jurisdiction over a nonresident parent in a child-support/custody context, focusing on minimum contacts and due process, not on what language a party may or should use in the prayer for relief. The opinion does not address or establish any rule about requesting modification of a custody order or “any other relief that [the court] deems just and proper.”
Kulko v. Superior Court of California, 4.relevant_excerpt: The question is whether the California Supreme Court correctly ‘weighed’ ‘the facts’… in applying the settled ‘constitutional standard’… that before state courts may exercise in personam jurisdiction over a nonresident, nondomiciliary parent of minor children domiciled in the State, it must appear that the nonresident has ‘certain minimum contacts [with the forum State] such that the maintenance of the suit does not offend “traditional notions of fair play and substantial justice.”’ International Shoe Co. v. Washington, 326 U.S. 310, 316 (1945).

Koch v. Koch, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 58 (1988.proposition: WHEREFORE, the Plaintiff respectfully requests that this Honorable Court grant the requested modification of the custody order and any other relief that it deems just and proper.
Koch v. Koch, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 58 (1988.case_name: Aetna Casualty & Surety Co. v. Cotter
Koch v. Koch, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 58 (1988.support_reasoning: The proposition is a standard request for relief in a custody modification motion, concerning family law and the court’s remedial authority. Koch v. Koch, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 58 (1988), as excerpted, deals with insurance coverage, an insurer’s duty to defend, and interpretation of homeowner’s policy exclusions. It does not address custody, domestic relations, or the form of prayers for relief, so it provides no authority for the stated proposition.
Koch v. Koch, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 58 (1988.relevant_excerpt: “On the complaint as pleaded there was neither coverage nor a duty to defend. Summary judgment was rightly allowed. Judgment affirmed.”

Grubert v. Grubert, 20 Mass. Grubert v. Grubert concerns division of marital property and alimony on divorce, not modification of custody, and it does not discuss standards for granting such a modification or the propriety of that form of request. Therefore, the case does not provide legal authority supporting this specific proposition.
